content.body: benschwarz: wfm
hm, turns out we have a help.whatwg.org already, looks like it's run by MikeSmith
wakes up

I'm just to the first one to have put anything up on help.whatwg.org I guess
I'm happy if anybody wants to put whatever else they'd like there
http://forums.whatwg.org/viewtopic.php?t=11
Hixie: I think syntax.whatwg.org might have been intended for hosting that relaxng and datatype library for the validator
"I found the DTD file for the HTML 5.0 Draft. <http://syntax.whatwg.org/sgml/html5core+wf2/pre1/dtd>"
*the relaxng schemas
MikeSmith: That was http://syntax.whattf.org/, I thought
Philip`: yeah
syntax.whatwg.org is empty as far as i can tell
i guess i'll delete it for now
can always add it back if it's actually useful
http://www.w3.org/mid/AANLkTikqcJmCoHfRo1JwzW+s_jp5PsmaZ3mHnEEwq_Cn⊙mgc pretty much summarises the problem with making decisions based on consensus
Hixie: are you not in good standing with the AX TF?
dunno, what is "good standing" for the tf?
that wasn't what i was referring to, though
i just meant, the idea of deciding whether a group agrees to something or not being resolved by defining the group as those who agree
either through gerrymandering or attrition
speaking of, do you read the public-canvas-api list or know what they are up to?
js asi is evil
hober: congrats (saw your tweet)
brendaneich console.log\n(1, eval)();
great word, gerrymandering
jamesr_: i read it, wasn't aware they were up to anything
jamesr_: anything in particular?
Hixie: they keep talking about a shadow DOM in canvas and i'm not sure what they mean if it isn't fallback content
they seem to be discussing what the spec says without realising the spec has said it for several months now
the idea is that the fallback content of a <canvas> is supposed to be focusable even when the <canvas> isn't falling back
so that you can make the fallback reflect the image
this lets you get (for free) things like tabbing around controls
works in conjunction with the drawFocusRing() method to automatically render focus rings on controls on the canvas
bga_: that is not JS ASI
bga_: the first rule of ASI-club is there's no insertion if there is no error
bga_: where is the error?
try in web inspector
hober: will you be working on things like http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=10694 ?
bga_: what happens? i'm not talking about web inspector, i'm talking about JS
in js file too
v8 concat two lines
and tries to call function
because sees call operator
in ff4 too
bga_: why do you think there's an error requiring semicolon insertion?
bga_: remember the first rule of ASI fight-club
if there's no error, there is no insertion
bga_: you're thinking the \n should cause a ; to be inserted?
v8 and ff4 are correct
yes but many ppl do not insert ; in js code
its trap :)
it's fine to use menu for menus, isn't it?
like return\n{}
js should has minimal count of traps for newbies imho
i mean, it says those "actions" can be links... and going to a different page is an immediate action, isn't it?
bga_, jslint helps
aho its spike-nail
what's that supposed to mean?
english dictonary fail. sorry
i mean crutch
yes, it is
but if it's integrated into your text editor or IDE, it's not much of an issue
may be is better to fix lang issue instead keep "backward compatibility"?
you can't really fix js
it's out there... gotta deal with it
i mean new es6
js is the least of my problems though
js has alot of traps, bugs and fails imho
it's very straightforward imo
or i too critical
man there's all kinds of things that aren't specced right for type=email multiple
i write lots of js and it's generally completely pain-free
oh it's the Hixie :) is it fine to use menu for menus? :f
hm?
what do you mean by "menus"?
top/side navigation bar thingies
those things which are typically done with ul elements
"The menu element represents a list of commands."
if your "navigation bar" is a list of commands, then sure
and a command can be a link... and going to some site is some immediate action...
so... uhm... it's fine, isn't it?
is a command, per the html spec, yes
thing is, i kinda prefer using menu instead of ul for those things, since i wont have to re-reset them and because i think menu makes a little bit more sense than ul
from the html spec's point of view, either is defensible
thank you :x
<menu> really is intended for drop-down menus (type=toolbar) and context menus (type=context), the list state (no type attribute) is basically only allowed for historical reasons
<nav> is the important thing to have in your DOM if you have a navigation list
ye, nav>menu>li>a ish

whether you do

...

...

,
  • ...
  • ...
,

...

...

, or
  • ...
  • ....
    • is really up to you
kay :)
bga_, the closure compiler also helps you to write somewhat more robust js. there is also the option to skip js entirely (e.g. by using GTW, pyjamas, and things like that)
i know
es4 was very good
bga_: opinions vary on that
bga_: js has only a few such "I expected ASI here but i forgot the ASI-club rules" cases -- return is another, yet python (and ruby i think) have that one too
bga_: being only somewhat line oriented is a hard spot, i agree -- significant newlines all over, or nowhere, seem better
bga_: CoffeeScript goes hard the significant-newlines way
harder than python even -- no colon to separate condition from consequent, e.g. (if foo:\n  bar() in python is if foo\n  bar in coffee)
Hixie: maybe! I'll let you know after I start. :)

erlehmann: beats me
sweet Error500 http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-httpstate-cookie

http://blog.mozilla.com/rob-sayre/2011/01/04/skating-to-where-the-puck-is-going-to-be/ -- more reasons for having competing browsers
at some point I should collect them
(though these are somewhat more generic, not really tied to having different rendering engines)
hober, btw, anything in particular you'll be working on?
annevk: This is Apple. If he tells you he will have to kill you. And everyone you have ever spoken to. Including himself. Not really worth it.
jgraham, so the interwebs?
I see their evil plan now :)
But I know what plenty of people at Apple are doing... Maybe I should do something about security...
still hoping that one day Ubuntu gets their QA act together...
hsivonen: I think they could if they really wanted to
it's just that they don't really want to
calculated tradeoff at your expense
hsivonen: Ubuntu has QA?
But, seriously, I imagine doing QA for Ubuntu would be a nightmare
heh
I mean there is a roughly infinite amount of hardware to test, you don't control much of the code you are shipping, and it's not really clear how you automate all the things you might want to test
add to that the fact that you have lots of users demanding that you get "stable" updates out to them as often as possible
MikeSmith: I'm slowly digging myself out from under my todo list of unpushed patches. I just pushed a couple of yours to the htmlparser repo.
(It looks like approvals on Gecko 2.0 patches are slow, so I went ahead and allowed the htmlparser repo get ahead of m-c)
ah cool
thanks
hsivonen: I've goth a couple other patches queued up for your review, but don't want to swamp you
(Microsoft have the advantage of roughly infinite amounts of money to buy hardware, control over most of the relevant code, and multi-year release cycles)
(Apple have the advantage of control over the hardware and software, control over the code, and multi-year release cycles)
(as well as roughly infinite money)
jgraham: hardware support regressions aren't the only thing I'm unhappy about
jgraham: they also shipped with broken gconf and leaky nautilus and leaky vinagre
about on every third logout, my ~/.gconf/ gets corrupted and I have to ssh into the box from my Mac to restore .gconf from a backup
wow
also, it's a good idea to kill vinagre and nautilus at least daily
that's pretty bad
hsivonen: Right, that's bad. Although leakiness is one of the harder things to pick up. But my point was that the difficulty level of shipping non-buggy Ubuntu is high
Especially compared to OSX
This is a problem, not an excuse
Leaky nautilus? I hadn't noticed.
jgraham: yes and yes
Admittedly, I rarely use Nautilus.
gsnedders: Nautilus provides the desktop by default
Even if you don't use the file manager
(which I don't)
(my nautilus seems to be well behaved though. Mind you I am on 10.04)
(dunno what vinagre is)

Sounds like a logo or avatar
yeah, you can change it in the admin settings for the repo
hey jgraham btw, over the break I made a bunch of updates to the HTML ES5 spec
http://sideshowbarker.github.com/es5-spec/
for one thing, all of the errata are not incorporated into the main body of the document
though they remain available as annotations also
for anybody who wants to know what changes since edition 5 was first published
I also incorporated all the additional changes that were made for edition 5.1
and made those available as annos as well
MikeSmith, oh ok
jgraham: and I added annos for all the stuff from http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Web_ECMAScript
MikeSmith: Awesome
plus I added a whole bunch of internal hyperlinks
aargh. why is bugzilla.validator.nu so slow? Is someone attacking it again?

(which seems to be 404 now)
looks like the validator process is eating up CPU...
no runaway memory behavior though, so I guess I'll let whoever is validating stuff do their thing
MikeSmith: Links seem to be sadly hard to distinguish visually
In Opera at least
yeah, I need to restyle them
suggestions welcome
the problem is that in some algorithms, there are lots of links
along with boldfaced stuff
Tyhat's true in HTML5. Just making them blue or whatever (no underline) would work
OK
hang on, I'll fix it now
jgraham: please reload and lemme know if it's an improvement or not

hsivonen: I don't remember if I pinged you set about this or not, but the one other parser patch I have is for implementing zcorpan 's request for reporting the names and locations of unclosed elements

cool

MikeSmith: thanks. taking a look now...
hmm. I think I'll write my review comments as a patch that applies on top of yours
there are some tweaks I'm inclined to make
eventually, it might make sense to try to expose the implied tags to the application through some long-term-supported API
MikeSmith: NetBeans patches the parser in order to maintain a data structure similar to the one you are adding
OK
I hope that patch is a decent basis for whatever else you have in mind to add
I really wasn't sure if it was the right approach or not
MikeSmith: my review comments are trivialities like the exact placement of the // [NOCPP[ stuff
ok
cool

in adam spec http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-httpstate-cookie-20, there are algorithm for
* creating cookies by the server
* storing cookies by the user agent
* sending cookies to the server
* parsing the cooking sent by the server
hsivonen: http://bugzilla.validator.nu/show_bug.cgi?id=689
but no algorithm for what servers should do when parsing the value sent by the client aka what should they do with "Cookie: …"
s/cooking/cookies/
MikeSmith: thanks
karlcow, servers can do whatever they want
karlcow:
"   The semantics of individual cookies in the Cookie header are not
defined by this document.  Servers are expected to imbue these
cookies with application-specific semantics."
http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-httpstate-cookie-20#section-4.2.2
there is a discussion about Cookie.py module and what they should do for parsing it, what is legal or not, etc.
and the different languages libraries are looking at each other
Java will do one thing, ruby another one and python another one.
karlcow: what are any of them doing at the library level with the header contents?
seems like they should just be treating it as an opaque string
and just passing it on as is to whatever app is using the library code
abarth deserves some extra credit for getting the word "imbue" into a spec
python's Cookie.py rejects colon, Java servlet allows it, perl allows it, I do not about ruby
hsivonen, s/2010/2011/ ?
seems like Cookie.py is wrong then
hsivonen, in the license file
http://cpansearch.perl.org/src/GAAS/libwww-perl-5.835/lib/HTTP/Cookies.pm

these libraries being used for clients and servers

annevk: because there are used in the design of clients and servers?
(just asking and trying to see if miss something in the reasonning)
I think what you miss is when you port an application from one language to another cookie semantics are the least of your troubles
if the libraries are used for clients as well obviously that part needs to be changed...
if they want to work with other servers anyway
there are always used in both ways.
sometimes by the same application such as a proxy

Yay, atob() has totally different error handling in different browsers.
figures
as a general rule, I tend to prefer majority implementations, biased slightly towards market share, and biased slightly against sillyness
if that helps
not sure to understand http://www.w3.org/html/wg/tracker/issues/149 for the examples. Is the change proposal to write all the examples, or to say that the examples have to be changed.

benschwarz: btw, while you're doing the developers.whatwg.org stuff, if you come across anything in the spec that is mis-labeled (class=impl when it shouldn't be, or vice versa, or something that just plain is more confusing in the author case for some reason), then don't hesitate to let me know so i can fix it

So, the breakdown is as follows: 1) Opera is super-lenient, and never throws.  2) Firefox is very strict, and atob() throws for most if not all things that btoa() can't produce (e.g., wrong number of trailing =).  3) WebKit is moderately strict, and throws only if the atob() input contains an invalid character or has an = except in a run at the end or has length 1 mod 4 after stripping trailing =.  4) IE9 is completely insane and I have no id
ea what it's doing, my entire test suite now fails (mostly with the error "'atob'/'btoa' is undefined").
Opinions?

WebKit is the least intuitive, since it tolerates some errors but not others.  I'm not sure whether strict errors are good or bad here, so I guess if it's a toss-up between Firefox and Opera, Firefox wins by market share.
But I'm generally inclined to think that it's nicer to be tolerant.
On a side note, IE9 thinks btoa("") is invalid, and it's not totally clear that's wrong from the RFC (since that's vague), so I'm leaning toward writing my own btoa() spec text.
WebKit also doesn't like strings that consist only of ='s.
I think I'll go with Firefox for now.
AryehGregor: Never throwing causes site-compat issues, FYI
Ah, okay.
That settles it.
Actually, Firefox doesn't throw errors for everything you might expect.
So I think I'll go with WebKit, since it throws in fewer cases and therefore is simpler to spec and implement.
looks in a, "do I want to know?" sort of way
gsnedders: I thought you knew everything
But maybe WebKit isn't web-compatible either . . . hmm.
looks in their Bugzilla
Hixie, any suggestions?  I think WebKit's behavior is simpler to spec, but perhaps it's less site-compatible.
AryehGregor: hard to say
AryehGregor: any idea what IE is doing?
(i feel your pain, when it comes to debugging IE)
Hixie, I was trying to test IE9 before, but now something I did in my test suite causes it to fail all tests with cryptic error messages.
I'll try doing more limited debugging and see if I can work out what it does, though.
weird
also try IE8, maybe it's just an IE9 beta bug
The test framework doesn't even work in IE8.
that's problematic :-)
It's possible that the actual IE bug is in ES5 features or something, since I don't really know what parts of JavaScript are new or whatever.
from your descriptions, it sounds like webkit is the sanest, but it also sounds like you might have some room to try to come up with something more logical than anyone currently implements
I don't think we need to care so much about IE, to be honest . . . it's usually in different code paths and it's already committed to breaking compat on every release with compatibility mode.
you'd be surprised how many pages just assume IE and don't have other code paths
but that's more about IE6 or 7 than IE9
remember that the goal is for the spec to be compatible with legacy content, not legacy UAs
Okay, IE9 is giving "'btoa' is undefined" for no discernible reason.
lameness
that's the reason :v
gotta go for lunch, but i can try to help out when i get back

will return to this in an hour or two
Does Microsoft have any official documentation for their JavaScript function implementation . . . ?

is the paste event standardized/ing ?
webr3: not yet, but we really should
hixie, best place to nudge re paste event (and aligning w/ drag and drop, and aligning TextInput event which seems to differ, and correlations to input event)
nowhere useful to nudge, we don't have an editor for it
for events 3?
for copy/paste
imho dom events should just define the events model, not the actual events
almost every event it tries to define it gets wrong somehow
or duplicates requirements elsewhere, or doesn't specify in enough detail for interop, etc

have to agree there, either the place for all events, or just the model, but if all it'd have to be more of a registry.. would be god to have a central place to look them all up and ensure they were all aligned when being defined though
events can't sanely be specced in a registry
events are like exceptions
how they fire is deeply integrated with the things they are talking about
the place to spec them is in the processing model for the relevant feature
doesn't make sense to spec them separately
at some level surely they can, for instance ensuring certain properties existed on all events of type input etc
it'll be even more of a pita if every single event has a different interface for the properties
the interfaces can be specced wherever, those are almost trivial
i'm talking about the rules for when the events fire
gotcha, i was talking more about the methods and properties on certain classes of event and ensuring they were aligned, .data vs .getData vs .clipboardData.getData(), with types without and so forth

getting them all aligned is mostly a lost cause, but yeah, for the simpler interfaces i'm fine with dom events speccing them -- there's not much to spec, the attributes are readonly and just return what the initialisers were given and there are no methods
other than the initialisers

hsivonen: I remember now that the reason I implemented the unclosed-element reporting using additional lists instead of just putting the locators on the stack nodes
the reason was, to have a way to essentially keep state about which unclosed elements had already been reported
because without that, many or most unclosed element instances cause duplicate error messages to be emitted
Hixie: Roger.
